name: Vegan Miso Soup
description: Made with kombu dashi, this authentic Japanese Vegan Miso Soup is filled with silken tofu and wakame, and packed with umami goodness! It's hands-down the easiest soup anyone can pull off on a busy weeknight.

itemListElement.text: Put 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) in 4 cups water and let it steep for 20 minutes, or as long as you can (maximum overnight).
itemListElement.name: Put 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) in 4 cups water and let it steep for 20 minutes, or as long as you can (maximum overnight).

itemListElement.text: Transfer the kombu and water to a pot. Bring it to near boiling point on medium heat. If you didn’t steep for a long time at Step 1, it’s good to slowly bring the kombu water to near boiling on low heat. Once the bubbles start to appear and it looks like almost boiling, remove the kombu and turn off the heat. If you leave the kombu in the water, the kombu dashi can become bitter. So, it’s usually recommended to take it out. Use this used kombu to make Simmered Kombu or Homemade Furikake (Rice Seasoning).
itemListElement.name: Transfer the kombu and water to a pot. Bring it to near boiling point on medium heat. If you didn’t steep for a long time at Step 1, it’s good to slowly bring the kombu water to near boiling on low heat. Once the bubbles start to appear and it looks like almost boiling, remove the kombu and turn off the heat. If you leave the kombu in the water, the kombu dashi can become bitter. So, it’s usually recommended to take it out. Use this used kombu to make Simmered Kombu or Homemade Furikake (Rice Seasoning).

recipeInstructions.name: To Prepare the Add-ins and Garnish

itemListElement.text: Rehydrate 1 Tbsp dried wakame seaweed in water for 5 minutes. Squeeze the water out and divide the wakame among the individual miso soup bowls.
itemListElement.name: Rehydrate 1 Tbsp dried wakame seaweed in water for 5 minutes. Squeeze the water out and divide the wakame among the individual miso soup bowls.

itemListElement.text: Cut 2 green onions/scallions into small pieces (diagonally—optional) and set aside in a small bowl.
itemListElement.name: Cut 2 green onions/scallions into small pieces (diagonally—optional) and set aside in a small bowl.

itemListElement.text: Set the miso soup bowls and green onion aside for now.
itemListElement.name: Set the miso soup bowls and green onion aside for now.

itemListElement.text: A typical Japanese miso soup bowl holds about 200 ml of liquid. Miso varies in saltiness depends on types and brands; but as a general rule, we add 1 tablespoon (20 g) of miso per one miso soup bowl (200 ml dashi). I use a miso muddler (one side measures 1 Tbsp, the other side 2 Tbsp). For this recipe, I use roughly 5 Tbsp miso. Tip: When you add the tofu, you may want to add an extra tablespoon (that’s why I add 5 Tbsp total) because tofu contains additional moisture which dilutes the miso soup.
itemListElement.name: A typical Japanese miso soup bowl holds about 200 ml of liquid. Miso varies in saltiness depends on types and brands; but as a general rule, we add 1 tablespoon (20 g) of miso per one miso soup bowl (200 ml dashi). I use a miso muddler (one side measures 1 Tbsp, the other side 2 Tbsp). For this recipe, I use roughly 5 Tbsp miso. Tip: When you add the tofu, you may want to add an extra tablespoon (that’s why I add 5 Tbsp total) because tofu contains additional moisture which dilutes the miso soup.

itemListElement.text: When you add the miso, turn off the heat (NEVER let miso soup boil). Scoop some dashi/soup into your ladle and let the miso dissolve in the ladle first using chopsticks or a whisk. Tip: Do not directly drop miso into the soup because you may end up with undissolved chunks of miso left in the soup. It’s very important to taste to check the saltiness.
itemListElement.name: When you add the miso, turn off the heat (NEVER let miso soup boil). Scoop some dashi/soup into your ladle and let the miso dissolve in the ladle first using chopsticks or a whisk. Tip: Do not directly drop miso into the soup because you may end up with undissolved chunks of miso left in the soup. It’s very important to taste to check the saltiness.

itemListElement.text: Cut 7 oz soft/silken tofu (kinugoshi dofu) into small cubes and add to the miso soup. (Please use a cutting board if you are not used to cutting it on your palm).
itemListElement.name: Cut 7 oz soft/silken tofu (kinugoshi dofu) into small cubes and add to the miso soup. (Please use a cutting board if you are not used to cutting it on your palm).

itemListElement.text: Reheat until hot (but not boiling) and serve. Tip: After adding miso, never let miso soup boil because it will lose aroma and flavor and also kill the probiotics in the miso.
itemListElement.name: Reheat until hot (but not boiling) and serve. Tip: After adding miso, never let miso soup boil because it will lose aroma and flavor and also kill the probiotics in the miso.

review.reviewBody:
This is absolutely AMAZING!!! 😺😺

I made way too much for just one person and it was a delight to eat it for my breakfast in the mornings. Love the alguea !!🥬 Thank you for all of the tips in handling the miso as well, I am very pleased with how this turned out, thanks to you 👍😚❤️❤️

About a year ago i started cooking for myself because i wanted to eat more healthier and lose some weight. After 6 months i became a vegetarian and try different regional style of cooking. About a month ago i wanted to try the Japanese cuisine and found this website. I already make some of the beautiful and delicious recipes from here and i fell in love with the Japanese kitchen. It’s a little bit hard to find all the ingredients here in the Netherlands where i live but in the Asian grocery store i can find most of the things i need. Today i was make this miso soup for the first time and i really enjoyed it. Thank you for the inspiration and wonderful recipes and stories.
thank you so much! have loved miso soup for 30+ years, can’t believe it took me so long to make it. your recipe was so clear and tasted great (made the vegan version).

Excellent instructions for a vegan who knows very little about Japanese cooking. Made the miso soup and my Japanese neighbor gave me wakame when I was explaining all I had was nori, lol. It was delicious!!!

This miso soup is so good! So simple to make too! 
Thank you for sharing this recipe.
